pyttn.oqs.bath_fitting.ESPRIT module

pyttn.oqs.bath_fitting.ESPRIT.ESPRIT(Ct, K)[source]

Implementation of the Estimation of Signal Parameters via Rotational Invariant Techniques (ESPRIT) method for decomposing a signal into the form

  1. Paulraj, R. Roy, and T. Kailath, Proceedings of the IEEE 74, 1044 (1986).

Parameters:

  • Ct (np.ndarray) – An array containing the values to be fit

  • K (np.ndarray) – The set of support points used for interpolating the function

Returns:

  • w(np.ndarray) - The weights in the decomposition

  • nu(np.ndarray) - The exponents in the decomposition

  • Ctfit(np.ndarray) - The function fit at the same points as the original Ct

pyttn.oqs.bath_fitting.ESPRIT.ESPRIT_frequencies(Ct, K)[source]

Extract the frequencies to be used in the ESPRIT algorithm

Parameters:

  • Ct (np.ndarray) – An array containing the values to be fit

  • K (np.ndarray) – The set of support points used for interpolating the function

Returns:

  • expnu(np.ndarray) - The exponential of the frequencies to be used in the ESPRIT decomposition

pyttn.oqs.bath_fitting.aaa module

pyttn.oqs.bath_fitting.aaa.AAA_algorithm(F, Z, tol=1e-13, nmax=100, *args, **kwargs)[source]

Implementation of the adaptive Antoulas-Anderson (AAA) algorithm for rational approximation Y. Nakatsukasa, O. Sète, and L. N. Trefethen, SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing 40, A1494 (2018).

Parameters:

  • F (callable) – The function to be fit

  • Z (np.ndarray) – The set of support points used for interpolating the function

  • tol (float, optional) – The convergence tolerance for the AAA algorithm. (default: 1e-13)

  • nmax (int, optional) – The maximum number of poles to use in the AAA fit. (default: 100)

  • *args – Variable length argument list to be passed to the F function

  • **kwargs – Arbitrary keyword arguments to be passed to the F function

Returns:

  • func - A function defining the rational function approximation

  • poles(np.ndarray) - The poles of the rational function

  • residues(np.ndarray) - The residues of the rational function decomposition

  • zeros(np.ndarray) - The zeros of the rational function

pyttn.oqs.bath_fitting.bath_discretisation module

class pyttn.oqs.bath_fitting.bath_discretisation.BathDiscretisation(Nb, wmin, wmax)[source]

Bases: object

Base class for bath discretisations

Parameters:

  • Nb (int) – The number of discrete points to find

  • wmin (float) – The minimum allowed frequency.

  • wmax (float) – The maximum allowed frequency.

class pyttn.oqs.bath_fitting.bath_discretisation.DensityDiscretisation(Nb, wmin, wmax, rho=None, atol=0, rtol=1e-10, nquad=100, wtol=1e-10, ftol=1e-10, niters=100, wcut=1e-08)[source]

Bases: BathDiscretisation

A class wrapping the density based discretisation approach. Selects frequencies from a density of frequencies \(\rho(\omega)\) according to the expression

\[\int_{\omega_{\mathrm{min}}}^{\omega_k} \rho(\omega)\mathrm{d} \omega = k,\]

with coupling constants then determined by

\[g_k^2 = \frac{1}{\pi} \frac{S(\omega_k)}{\rho(\omega_k)}.\]

Constructor arguments

Parameters:

  • Nb (int) – The number of discrete points to find

  • wmin (float) – The minimum allowed frequency.

  • wmax (float) – The maximum allowed frequency.

  • rho (callable or None, optional) – The density of frequencies to use in the discretisation process. (Default: None)

  • atol (float, optional) – Absolute tolerance to use in the evaluation of integrals within the discretisation process. (Default: 0)

  • rtol (float, optional) – Relative tolerance to use in the evaluation of integrals within the discretisation process. (Default: 1e-10)

  • nquad (int, optional) – The degree of the gauss-Legendre polynomial based quadrature scheme used in the evaluation of integrals. (Default: 100)

  • wtol (float, optional) – Frequency tolerance used in Newton’s method step for finding frequencies. (Default: 1e-10)

  • ftol (float, optional) – Error tolerance used in Newton’s method step for finding frequencies. (Default: 1e-10)

  • niters (int, optional) – The maximum number of Newton’s method iterations used to find frequencies. (Default: 100)

  • wcut (float, optional) – A lower bound on the frequency to cutoff the 1/w. (Default: 1e-8)

Callable arguments:

Parameters:

S (callable) – The spectral density function to be decomposed.

Returns:

  • g (np.ndarray) - The coupling constants of the discrete bath modes

  • w (np.ndarray) - The frequencies of the discrete bath modes

__call__(S)[source]

Call self as a function.

class pyttn.oqs.bath_fitting.bath_discretisation.OrthopolDiscretisation(Nb, wmin, wmax, moment_scaling=None, atol=0, rtol=1e-10, minbound=1e-25, maxbound=1e+25, moment_scaling_steps=4, nquad=100)[source]

Bases: object

A class wrapping the orthonormal polynomial based discretisation scheme. This scheme constructs a set of orthonormal polynomials satisfying the orthogonality constraint

\[\int_{\omega_{\mathrm{min}}}^{\omega_\mathrm{max}} S(\omega) \pi_i(\omega) \pi_j(\omega) \mathrm{d}\omega = \delta_{ij}.\]

The coupling constants and frequencies are then obtained from the weights and nodes, respectively, of the Gaussian quadrature rule associated with these orthonormal polynomials.

Constructor arguments

Parameters:

  • Nb (int) – The number of discrete points to find

  • wmin (float) – The minimum allowed frequency.

  • wmax (float) – The maximum allowed frequency.

  • moment_scaling (float or None, optional) – A parameter to scale the frequency coordinate by in order to avoid over/underflows. (Default: None)

  • atol (float, optional) – Absolute tolerance to use in the evaluation of integrals within the discretisation process. (Default: 0)

  • rtol (float, optional) – Relative tolerance to use in the evaluation of integrals within the discretisation process. (Default: 1e-10)

  • minbound (float, optional) – A parameter for early bailout of the moment scaling step due to underflows. (Default: 1e-25)

  • maxbound (float, optional) – A parameter for early bailout of the moment scaling step due to overflows. (Default: 1e-25)

  • moment_scaling_steps (int, optional) – The number of iterations of moment scaling to perform. (Default: 4)

  • nquad (int, optional) – The degree of the gauss-Legendre polynomial based quadrature scheme used in the evaluation of integrals. (Default: 100)

Callable arguments:

Parameters:

S (callable) – The spectral density function to be decomposed.

Returns:

  • g (np.ndarray) - The coupling constants of the discrete bath modes

  • w (np.ndarray) - The frequencies of the discrete bath m

__call__(S)[source]

Call self as a function.

find_moment_scaling_factor(wmin, wmax, Nb, atol=0, rtol=1e-10, minbound=1e-30, maxbound=1e+30, Nsteps=5, nquad=100)[source]

Finds a constant to scale the frequency axis by in order to ensure well defined scaling of the modified moments as we go to very high moments. here this is done by computing the modified moments up to varying orders (with early termination if the values leave some min and max bounds) and fitting the resultant decay or growth to an exponential function. Based on this fitting we extract a constant that aims to minimise the decay or growth, and repeats this process with growing orders (up to the maximum order we need for the discretisation) until it reaches a point that the moment decay does not leave the early termination bounds. This may not always be optimal if the Nsteps variable is too large and in this case either try reducing Nsteps.

Parameters:

  • S (callable) – The spectral density function to be decomposed.

  • wmin (float) – The minimum allowed frequency.

  • wmax (float) – The maximum allowed frequency.

  • Nb (int) – The number of discrete points to find

  • atol (float, optional) – Absolute tolerance to use in the evaluation of integrals within the discretisation process. (Default: 0)

  • rtol (float, optional) – Relative tolerance to use in the evaluation of integrals within the discretisation process. (Default: 1e-10)

  • minbound (float, optional) – A parameter for early bailout of the moment scaling step due to underflows. (Default: 1e-25)

  • maxbound (float, optional) – A parameter for early bailout of the moment scaling step due to overflows. (Default: 1e-25)

  • Nsteps (int, optional) – The number of iterations of moment scaling to perform. (Default: 4)

  • nquad (int, optional) – The degree of the gauss-Legendre polynomial based quadrature scheme used in the evaluation of integrals. (Default: 100)

pyttn.oqs.bath_fitting.expfit module

class pyttn.oqs.bath_fitting.expfit.AAADecomposition(tol=0.0001, w='linear', aaa_nmax=500, coeff=1.0, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: object

A class providing an easy to use interface for applying the AAA based rational function decomposition to approximate a bath spectral density. This class includes tools used for automatic generation of support points, as well as manually specified support points to allow for both easy general use and flexibility when handling more complex spectral densities.

Constructor arguments:

Parameters:

  • tol (float, optional) – The tolerance used within the AAA algorithm. (Default: 1e-4)

  • w (str or np.ndarray or list, optional) – Either the support points or a key word used to generate the support points. For details see the AAA_support_points function. (Default: “linear”)

  • aaa_nmax (int, optional) – The maximum number of poles to allow within the AAA algorithm. (Default:500)

  • coeff (float, optional) – A coefficient to go in front of the frequency terms. (Default: 1)

  • **kwargs – Keyword arguments to pass to AAA_support_points

Callable arguments:

Parameters:

S (callable) – The spectral density function to be decomposed.

Returns:

  • dk (np.ndarray) - The coefficients in the sum-of-exponential decomposition of the bath correlation function

  • zk (np.ndarray) - The exponents in the sum-of-exponential decomposition of the bath correlation function

  • func (callable) - The AAA rational function fit of the spectral density

__call__(S)[source]

Perform the AAA decomposition on the function S.

Parameters:

S (callable) – The spectral density function to be decomposed.

Returns:

  • dk (np.ndarray) - The coefficients in the sum-of-exponential decomposition of the bath correlation function

  • zk (np.ndarray) - The exponents in the sum-of-exponential decomposition of the bath correlation function

  • func (callable) - The AAA rational function fit of the spectral density

pyttn.oqs.bath_fitting.expfit.AAA_support_points(w='linear', wmin=None, wmax=None, Naaa=1000)[source]

A function for automatically generating support points to be used within the AAA algorithm.

Parameters:

  • w (str or np.ndarray or list, optional) –

    Either the support points orr a key word used to generate the support points. (Default: “linear”) This parameter can be either a

    • list/np.ndarray: In this case the function simply returns these points as the support points ignoring all other inputs

    • str: In this case the function generates points according to a rule using the user specified wmin, wmax, Naaa. Possible options for this argument are

      • linear: Use a linear set of grid points between wmin and wmax

      • softm: Use a softmspace (interpolates between linear and logarithmic) for positive frequencies and a mirrored set of points for negative frequencies

  • wmin (float or None, optional) – The minimum allowed frequency. (Default: None)

  • wmax (float or None, optional) – The maximum allowed frequency. (Default: None)

  • Naaa (int or None, optional) – The number of support points used by the AAA algorithm. (Default: 1000)

class pyttn.oqs.bath_fitting.expfit.ESPRITDecomposition(K, t='linear', **kwargs)[source]

Bases: ExpFitDecomposition

A class providing an easy to use interface for applying the ESPRIT decomposition to construct a sum-of-exponential approximation for a bath correlation function

Constructor arguments:

Parameters:

  • K (int) – The number of terms in the sum-of-exponential decomposition

  • t (str or np.ndarray or list, optional) – Either the support points orr a key word used to generate the support points. For details see the ESPRIT_support_points function. (Default: “linear”)

  • **kwargs – Keyword arguments to pass to ESPRIT_support_points

Callable arguments:

Parameters:

Ct (callable) – The non-interacting bath correlation function to be decomposed.

Returns:

  • dk (np.ndarray) - The coefficients in the sum-of-exponential decomposition of the bath correlation function

  • zk (np.ndarray) - The exponents in the sum-of-exponential decomposition of the bath correlation function

  • Ctres (callable) - The ESPRIT fit of the bath correlation function

pyttn.oqs.bath_fitting.expfit.ESPRIT_support_points(t='linear', tmax=None, Nt=1000)[source]

A function for automatically generating support points to be used within the ESPRIT algorithm.

Parameters:

  • t (str or np.ndarray or list, optional) –

    Either the support points or a key word used to generate the support points. (Default: “linear”) This parameter can be either a

    • list/np.ndarray: In this case the function simply returns these points as the support points ignoring all other inputs

    • str: In this case the function generates points according to a rule using the user specified tmax, and Nt. Possible options for this argument are

      • linear: Use a linear set of grid points between wmin and wmax

  • tmax (float or None, optional) – The maximum allowed time. (Default: None)

  • Nt (int or None, optional) – The number of time points to use with the ESPRIT algorithm. (Default: 1000)
